fields.title: On delivering a pizza
fields.body:
When I get to the store from my last delivery I try to find my next order
I see your name before I ever see your face
Know your address before we have spoken a word
Once I find the correct half scratched off number on your mailbox I park my car and rush to your door
As I knock and wait I try to think of something new to say
Saying the same thing all night tends to get dull
“Good evening, here’s your pizza.”
You say thank you
“Sign here, keep the bottom copy.”
While you sign and think of how much to tip me, I look away out of some unnamed courtesy
I see the receipt that you hand back to me
I politely say good night and leave as you say the same and close your door

I don’t think there is a word for that
That feeling between two passing strangers
Knowing so little, and so much of the person that looks back
They are always different
They are always similar in someway though too
Some of them I will never see again
Some of them will never think of me again
And yet I gave them a pizza
How beautiful pizza is

fields.title: Crushed by a Red Bull
fields.body:
I am a RedBull
crushed by the pressure of society and out of energy
They tell me I have to get busy living or get busy dying
But I better not take it easy or enjoy my life
I need to have wings to fly
Instead of walking peaceably on the ground
I’m crushed by the realization that I’m not my own
I’m a money making busy bee programmed by society to regain my energy when I’m tired rather than taking a nap

I am a Red Bull
Charging and stomping at everything that I hate
Not realizing that the red I see is coated on me
I’m a hypocrite
I am what I hate in others and I criticize the world
My corner of society is as bad as yours
Yet I blame my problems on those who have the least control of them
So I gore them to death and stomp on their will to survive
Grandpa always said “If you run with wolves, you’ll howl with them”, but he never told us running with the bulls is deadly

fields.title: On March 3, 2020
fields.body:
a twist of fate
25 dead and counting
officials say stay home but the good Samaritan never sleeps
buildings destroyed
with no prejudice to race sex age or status
mother nature reminds us she is still in control
don’t sleep too heavy or you might not wake
tears fall with the same ferocity as raindrops
welcome to Nashville
we can’t control the weather but we weather the aftermath pretty well

fields.title: A young dead boy and an empty journal
fields.body:
Driving to school one morning, listening to music, contemplating the next three months of class, and thinking about his future. He’s a writer and thinker with a line or two in his mind. He just got a new journal and is planning the first page. Thinking of lines, not paying attention to the lines on the road. For the first time he’s hopeful for the plans that he’s laid, and that hope is running into the lines in his head.

He’s a good kid, but he’s had his dark streaks. He’s lost a lot of ink to the surface of paper, and he’s lost a lot of words to his instinct for poetry.
All alone, he contemplates self.
All alone, he fixes his health.

Drunk driver meets rainy roads, our man can’t tell the future, so he doesn’t know to look.
Silver Cadillac, SUV, flips the Corolla, XSE.
His head is hurt, and his car’s in the ditch. It’s getting warmer, but he wants to sleep. Didn’t see the gas leaking, so he slept through the fire.

When the paramedics arrive, they can’t ID the young man. The police report will say that he was gripping a leather bound journal when they pulled him from the wreckage. The journal was as badly burned and unrecognizable.

The family knew days before they got the call from metro police. He never misses family dinner, and he hadn’t called in over four days.

When they got to the morgue, laying on the table was,
A young dead boy and an empty journal.
